Well, as might have been expected, the announced launch of [Tutorials Quest] has resurrected the issues/arguments about how the [Tutorials] section is managed, with regard to how tutorials do/should get posted.

I wanted to just dismiss [dbwiz]'s [id://623839|complaints], but in thinking about it I think there is in fact something suboptimal which needs to be corrected. The problem is that "being a tutorial" (and an analogous situation applies in most of the other sections as well) means two different things:
1. being a node of type [perltutorial]
2. being linked in the [Tutorials] list
As it stands, there is no mechanism to enforce that these two conditions are synchronized, as there is for other sections. The [Pedagogues] have the power to un-list [perltutorial] nodes they deem of insufficient quality; and they can include in the [Tutorials] list nodes of any other type (mostly just [perlmeditation]) which are considered to be worthy.

The problem stems from the fact that the site's [Super Search|searching capability] only looks at node type, not at where the node is linked. So people searching for something in just [Tutorials] will in fact only be looking at nodes of type [perltutorial], including all the crappy ones, and possibly not finding nodes which they clearly see listed in [Tutorials].

There is a simple fix for this: [Pedagogues] should be able to ask [Janitors] to switch the type of a node to/from [perltutorial], with essentially no questions asked. (I know it sounds like a lot to ask, so if [Janitors] wanted to have some kind of additional check in place, I guess that would be fine.) This circumvents the consideration process, which, based on the threads [id://623839|raised by] [dbwiz], was mostly ineffective, and I don't think it should be up to the voting public to decide anyway. The only other opinion which should be considered, imho, is the author's: obviously, if an author doesn't want her writeup converted to [perltutorial], we should respect that, but it should come with the consequence that her overlooked gem won't get listed in [Tutorials] either. Similarly, if someone posts a crappy tutorial, we should be able to summarily demote it to Meditations, or something.

[jdporter], [localtime://2007-01-22 11:03:14]

The [/borg]ing mechanism does not currently support logging a reason directly. In fact, the list of borg'ed users is stored as a settings list, not in a "full-blown" db table. A setting list is essentially a hash. This setting's key is the borg'ed user's ID, and the value is the epoch time at which the [/borg] expires. Adding a "reason" field to this scheme is possible, though not nearly as trivial as adding a column to a regular db table. Unless and until such an enhancement is made, logging the reason for a [/borg] will be fairly manually intensive. This here [Cabalists' Wiki] could be used for the purpose, but keep in mind that it is readable only by [Cabal], not rank-and-file monks. (Or should I say, pawn monks.)

[davido], [localtime://2006-07-18 02:34:07]

A thought: We recently had a thread named "trinary operator". It got considered for title change to "ternary operator" for the sake of navagability and searchability. Clearly the [doc://perlop|POD] calls it the ternary operator, and when you do a Google search, there are something like 62k hits for "ternary operator". But there are also 4k hits for "trinary operator", and we see it misspelled (or spelled in an alternate way, perhaps) from time to time here. This tells me that while ternary is probably correct, there's a lot of propensity for people to use the other spelling (mistakenly or otherwise).

My suggestion is that rather than being in a hurry to retitle them, instead, post a Q&A question with the following two titles: "Trinary operator, see also the more common spelling: ternary operator.", and "Ternary operator, see also the less common spelling: trinary operator." Doing so will result in those titles being found anytime someone uses the search box to search for either of the terms, thus providing an aid to navigation right when it's needed most.

The body of each of those nodes could contain a very brief explanation of why the node exists (an aid to navigation) and why it might be beneficial to search for both terms.

Maybe this will be considered to be too much coddling, but it might just help a few people along the way. Comments?
